pr_title: JENA-1830: Put LTS in default travis-ci setup

timeline.message: JENA-1830: Put LTS in default travis-ci setup

timeline.bodyText:
What about including the next version(s) too as allowed failures?
We use that in commons - https://github.com/apache/commons-lang/blob/master/.travis.yml#L27
timeline.author: kinow
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -4,9 +4,6 @@ install: true
 script: mvn -B clean install
 jdk:
   - openjdk8
-  - openjdk9

replies.bodyText:
How do "allow_failures" get reported?  Does it still send out an email alert?
If we had travis tied to, for example, project github actions, having a (non-failing) step for openjdk-ea makes sense. So if there is a preference and migration to use GH actions/Travis more (e.g. consolidating on GH for the sake of simplicity) then obviously this all needs revisiting in a new light.
ATM The travis file is for contributors. For the project, we do have Jenkins builds that reports as well. I'm not sure whether "allow fail" makes a difference - not sure people would look!
replies.author: afs

replies.bodyText:
Oh, that's a good question. As far as I can tell, they are not reported. At least I never got an e-mail for openjdk-ea (early-access) in Commons projects.
I think people wouldn't look. It would be more helpful for developers. But if that's handled in Jenkins, then I guess it's not necessary to have it in Travis.
Link to allow_failures doc: https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build#rows-that-are-allowed-to-fail
replies.author: kinow
